subComponents.description: As in earlier versions of the model (Rotstayn et al., 2007), we uniformly increased the emissions of black carbon (by 25%) and organic carbon (by 50%) to improve the agreement between modelled and observed fields of carbonaceous aerosol. Also, the relatively small emissions of BC from aviation were omitted.

subComponents.description:
There are 11 prognostic variables in the aerosol scheme: dimethyl sulfide (DMS), sulfur dioxide (SO2), sulfate, hydrophobic and hydrophilic forms of black carbon and organic carbon, and four size bins of mineral dust (with radii ranging from 0.1-1, 1-2, 2-3
and 3-6 μm). A further two modes of sea salt are diagnosed as a function of wind speed in the marine boundary layer, but are not treated prognostically. In addition, the
distribution of stratospheric aerosol from volcanic eruptions is prescribed using monthly mean data (extended from Sato et al., 1993).

The up to date reference for the aerosol scheme is Rotstayn et al. (2012), with more detail in Rotstayn et al. (2007). Significant changes since then are inclusion of dust longwave radiative effects and an updated treatment of dust shortwave effects (Rotstayn et al., 2010, 2012). We slightly modified the treatments of indirect aerosol effects from those used by Rotstayn et al. (2010), to avoid the arbitrary tuning of parameters employed in that version of the model. The parameterisation of cloud droplet number concentration is now based on the relation from Jones et al. (1994), with aerosol number concentration derived from the mass concentrations of sulfate, sea salt and hydrophilic carbonaceous aerosol, assuming the same mass-to-number conversion factors that are used in the radiation scheme (Rotstayn et al., 2007).

subComponents.description:
Transport of aerosols and other trace quantities occurs
by advection, vertical turbulent mixing, and vertical transport
inside deep convective clouds [Rotstayn and Lohmann,
2002]. Vertical advection is handled using a flux-corrected
transport scheme [Van Leer, 1977], and horizontal advection
is handled via a semi-Lagrangian scheme [McGregor,
1993]. The treatment of vertical turbulent mixing is based
on stability-dependent K-theory [Louis, 1979]. Under convective
conditions, an additional nonlocal counter-gradient
flux is added [Holtslag and Boville, 1993]. Convective
transport is based on the vertical profiles of the updraft
mass flux and compensating subsidence generated by the
convection scheme [Gregory and Rowntree, 1990].

References and further details in Rotstayn, L. D., and U. Lohmann (2002), Simulation of the tropospheric sulfur cycle in a global model with a physically based cloud scheme, J. Geophys. Res., 107, 4592, doi:10.1029/2002JD002128.

subComponents.description:
There is a parameterisation to account for mixing in marginal seas and and in straits. Also to overcome the lack of background horizontal diffusion with the GM scheme, addtional diffusion has been set up near coasts and in closed in emabayments where no mixing was occuring. 
The amplitude of the mixing is 1.0 e3 multiplied a factor determined by a mask (2 for the Arctic coastline, Western Ross sea, Western Weddell Sea, Timor Straits, Straits of Gibralter . Whilst a value of 4 is used for the Baltic, North Sea, for the less connected parts of the Meditteranian,  for the Arabian Gulf and Red sea,  for Gulf of Thailand, and Malacca Strait, Gulf of Carpenteria, Hudson bay entrance and Canadian Archipeligo, Gulf of St Lawrence, Irish Sea, Southern gulf of Mexico. When these bays interface to the open ocean the value is stepped down to 2 for the adjacent grid box.
There is also extra horizontal mixing around all the coastlines of magnitude 1 e3 m2s-1 the above mask will override this value and additioanl horizontal mixing along the stormtracks determined by the wind stress curl.  These additional mixing terms are applied to the upper ocean grid boxes down to 80m depth with the edge mixing down to 280m depth.

responsibleParties.organisationName: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

subComponents.description: Small angle redi isopycnal tensor is used and the Gerdes, Koberle and Willebrand taper is used in the GM scheme.  Horizontal  diffusion  in steep regions is same as GM diffusion.

responsibleParties.organisationName: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

subComponents.longName: Ocean boundary conditions surface and bed.

responsibleParties.organisationName: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence
Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

subComponents.description: Uses Bryan and lewis background profile to describe interior mixing. This mixing has a latitudinal dependence with reduced valuses in the upper 2000m in the tropical region. from 15N-15S and vlended with the global value between 30n-30S. The global Bryan-Lewis profile is obtained using a tanh expression. Outside the tropics the bacground mixing value is approx 0.3 e-4 m2s-1 in the upper 300m increasing to 1.3e-4 m2s-1 by approx 3000m depth . In the tropics the surface values are reduced above 2000m depth at 1500m =0.2e-4 m2s-1, at 1100m is 0.15e-4 m2s-, at 500m 0.11e-4 m2s-1, at 280m 0.095e-4m2s-1 at 100m is 0.02e-4m2s-1, at 40m 0.002e-4 m2s-1.

responsibleParties.organisationName: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

subComponents.description: Three schemes are included, Kraus Turner which is effective in mid and high latitudes. In the tropics the thermocline mixing is by Interger power scheme Wilson (1999) which is an extension of Pacakanowski and Philander scheme and Price Weller and Pinkel (1986) bulk Richardon number scheme that impacts the tropical mixing and lowers the thermocline depth whilst mainining the thermocline strength that was determined by the integer power scheme.

subComponents.description: The sea ice model is part of the atmospheric model code, coupling to the ocean is done at the base of the embedded mixed layer.

responsibleParties.organisationName: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

subComponents.description: The velocities close to the polar are filtered using an fft filter identical to that used in the ocean.

values: Formulated in terms of divergence field
25000 * ice depth *ice depth exp (-20 (1- ice conc))

responsibleParties.organisationName: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

subComponents.description: ocean to ice heat flux is rhocw*dz*antarc*(To-Tfi)/((dz/2)**2), where dz is depth of top ocean layer, rhocw (density x heat capicity) =4.1e6, To is ocean temperature in top ocean layer, Tfi is freezing point -1.85 C and antarc =0.075 e-4

values: Bare ice 0.65 unless surface temp > -0.2 C then 0.60. Snow albedo 0.80 unless surface temp > -0.05C then 0.70
When new is is formed the volume is mintained but it is gathered into pancake ice 25cm thick
Multi-layer on a regular vertical grid
